alternatives.transcript: good evening everyone welcome to the last event in our two-day ETS conference I found this to have been a terrific experience I've learned a lot and I think from things I've heard from a lot of you I hope that you share my sentiments you all know who's going to be speaking with us this evening Jeff Bible I know that we all know the details and the intricacies of our tasks and addressing this very important issue to the business in ensuring that our consumers are in able to use our

Dias accommodating manner in places that they choose to but I know that you'll agree with me that we like to hear Jess views and his Challenge from Senior Management to all of us as to what their expectations are and his expectations are for us as well so without further Ado Jeff would you join us and let us know what your thoughts are

well thanks Matt but I thought Tom very nervous the met me tell you I'm nervous I thought this through I'm nervous because when I was in the Army and I think of all of you guys in corporate Affairs as being our infantry forces in the front line in the trenches
and I spent a number of years in the Army and I was in the Infantry
I think they call it the advanced infantry but there's nothing Advanced about an intellectual skills were just a bunch of mugs

but we were told to move forward whatever who told him the forward and we moved forward and the general was always telling us he was right behind us and I've always worried a lot about about that not come back to that later

but the difference between the Infantry forces I worked with in those days and the analogy I make with the group here this evening and other corporate Affairs people around the world is that you're all intellectually equipped and so what I'm talking to you I'm not talking to the Infantry guys that I was talking more working with I'm talking to what I think is the cream of our people

who not only have to sort of live with the shock waves that come every day in the stress that's associated with that but have to live with the orders and the difficulties of working with a big company and I find a little difficult to stand up here and pontificate about things when I know the Tremors that you have to face out there every day and the difficulties in the environment I'm aware of work with it to a certain degree

I have somebody here Phil you can who's been his work with me for a few years many years ago in trying to cope with a country that I think is one of our biggest difficulties today in Australia and I don't know that I made a good fist of it then I learned a lot from trying to get out of the trenches but I do appreciate the difficulties and that's why I'm nervous so if you'll bear with me when I say these words and then I'll try to take some questions I'm very nervous about that too but if you're

with me and I'm saying what I'm going to say with a lot of humidity so thank you for asking me to be part of this very important event I hope it's been useful stimulating and informative for all of you and is you've been able to refine the Strategic objectives that you will pursue the policies you'll Implement and establish the resources which enable you to achieve everything that you are setting out to do

I hope that you have a renewed sense of confidence in your abilities to manage the ETF issue to the advantage of Philip Morris companies because that is what we urgently need you to do in that regard your conference is very well timed indeed here in the US our government's recent decision on environmental tobacco smoke strikes yet another unfair and unjustifiable blue at individual freedom to use our
it summons us to redouble our efforts to protect that freedom and the health of our business
concerns over the alleged health effects of ETS are already driving the increase in restrictions on smoking in the workplace in the hospitality sector on public transportation and even in the home

these restrictions may be voluntary as is often the case in the workplace or they may be mandated by a legislative or regulatory intervention but regardless of their origin if they prohibit smokers from using our products during most of their waking hours they represent a direct threat to our business

and what's more the anti-smoking Crusaders know all too well to the extent that restrictions whatever their Source also stigmatize smokers and smoking they further erode our customer base so your efforts to block further restrictions on smoking are indeed critical to the future of Philip Morris companies

I think we're very conscious of that today what makes the ETS issue doubly difficult is the fact that it is really two challenges in one first as the public policy challenge because to some extent the decisions on ETS will be made by government officials and in this respect ETS is like most of the public policy threats you deal with whether they be matters of Taxation for marketing freezer or whatever

they arise and specific circumscribed contexts in legislators in committees and in Regulatory Agencies and the stuff that is for you to fight in these Arenas at least you have an arena you have the advantage of a focal point for your efforts so you can evaluate the disposition of legislatures and ascertain which staff has to work on

you can identify third parties to help carry your messages and you can establish a time frame within which to operate in short you can manage the issues within the classic parameters of time place and cast of characters but the other challenge lies in the special nature of the ETS issue it must be fought not only in the political area but also outside
in the streets in the noisy contentious and not always rational Marketplace of ideas decision about ETS come not only from legislatures and Regulatory but from consumers themselves

and if consumers are so stigmatized as to feel ill at ease when they smoke because they believe everything with the government and the media say about ETS and its effect on non-smokers then that we're faced with a public relations problem of enormous impact

so how can we communicate the facts to smokers and non-smokers are like and thus alleviate the unwarranted anxiety about ETS how can we encourage a rational approach that will promote accommodation of both smoker and nonsmoker

and how do we educate our consumers to understand that their decision to smoke is not the threat to their co-workers friends and family that the anti smokers would have them believe it is it's truly an uphill struggle

the one thing the public is skeptical about anything we say although it often accepts conclusions based upon junk science especially if they come from the government and probably Hillary most of all which is assumed to have no agenda of its own
and it's an uphill struggle because the public has a somewhat irrational perception of the nature of risk
that last point the nature of risk is worthy of comment because in this respect the societies we come from are not unique in Zaire for example there is a tribe that is three things most of all
being struck by lightning the inability of women to conceive and bronchitis
of course the tribe is acceptable to all the diseases and maladies you find in the problem that these three things of feared above all because they're believed to be punishments for misconduct

the reason in the words of Neil all of whose director of the center for Environmental Research at Cornell University is that and I quote people do not focus on a particular set of risks simply in order to safeguard health and safety the choice also reflects the view of moral and immoral conduct
dangers are exaggerated or minimized according to the social acceptability of the underlying activities

well from that you'll see the connection between the social acceptability of smoking and the perceived risk of ETS between the stigmatizing of smokers and the imposition of public smoking restrictions
it's clear then that you are engaged in public relations in its classical definition the engineering of consent

your task is to make sure the public smokers and non-smokers are like gets information that is bounced and scientifically valid so it's smokers can make informed decisions about how when and where to smoke smokers and non-smokers can accommodate each other in every sort of public facility and all of this can happen in an environment of free choice and mutual agreement untouched as much as possible
by the heavy hand of government coercion

your fault better the technical details and I will ever be and I don't remind you of the key to effective persuasion know your audience and tailor your message to it and even though some audiences may seem impossible to persuade keep trying different strategies and approaches until you hit upon the one that works
I'd also assure you Senior Management support
we're keenly aware of the importance of this issue to our business
and we stand ready to help you in any way we can
I know that one of the objectives of your conference is to identify the resources you need
well I'll certainly listen to your recommendations and I think everybody will and if they call for additional resources will certainly do our best to respond
finally I'd leave you with these words from Emily Dickinson
truth is such a rare thing it's such a joy to tell it
your mission difficult as it is is to tell the truth nothing more and nothing less and you go about it I wish you not only joy but all the luck and success in the world
those were my prepared remarks which would put a lot of thought into
and I thought I'd just add one or two words at the end if I can get away of them having spent some years trying to fight in the trenches which you spend all your time doing
I'm often reminded of political Corelli Barnett which most of you probably have heard of he wrote a book about Winston Churchill
and he wasn't a fan of wisdom Churchill but
one of the reasons he put in his book was that it used to irritate him that Winston Churchill would sit at home and with a wave of a cigar
over a map mudra great brigades around Europe willy-nilly

and I often worry that you guys must feel that with the way that the cigar over a map he tell you what to do and how to go about which is a little bit of what I've done and I don't want you to go away with that sense at all because that's not what I'm trying to say I feel badly that I for once it in the glass box in Rye Brook
travel around the world that that but I'm not in the trenches As You Are

I know how stressful a task this is and there's a word they use in French call carbon easy which you can understand what that means you've been carbonized or flamed up and it is a business where you can easily be carbonized in my opinion I recognize that I know the difficulties to a certain degree that you're faced with I want you to know that I appreciate that and in fact I think all of Senior Management

the stress of this sort of work has attached to it so what I said here that we're right behind you and I said earlier the general say we're right behind you charge and we all rush off and charge well I stay up behind you the best I can say is that if you need my help I'll certainly give it as best I can and in the trenches if you feel like it ever do that for you but if you need resources and they can be sensibly shown to be needed I'll be

the first to come through and make sure that you get them I don't think anything has a higher profile in Philip Morris today other than the share price then this issue the whole issue of corporate the corporate Affairs ETS in particular has a very high-profile right now
I wouldn't like you to go away that with a feeling that they're go these guys again saying empty words but we never see them up in the front line with a rifle in their hands
that would be a Pity because I'd hope you'd feel that we are sincerely with you and that we mean that and that we will give you what you need
I could go on and on and I might just start to sound empty but I'm saying it sincerely test me and I will come through thank you very much for inviting me
